item.description:
@sup000 wrote:

i should have covered these subjects myself so dont blame the course/teachers.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:20, topic:249929”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=329482.msg2580415#msg2580415 date=1229230687]

You could use an “else” block, I chose not to.

By not using ‘else if’ statements, you are making the JVM check all three statements every time the method is called…

You don’t want to use ‘else if’ there, because there are 3 different boolean variables. All, some, or none of the statements could be true.
[/quote]

Not in the bank’s example. He only has a single parameter and is checking exact equality. Only one will can possibly be true, yet doesn’t have to be. That’s why I think it’d be minutely more efficient to simply use ‘else if’ statements for the second two conditionals, instead of having the JVM check them as well, even if the first (or second) were already true.[/quote]I agree, however like I said, if they haven’t been taught booleans, I doubt they have been taught ‘else if’.

Read full topic

@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:249929”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=329482.msg2579963#msg2579963 date=1229215340]

You could use an “else” block, I chose not to.

By not using ‘else if’ statements, you are making the JVM check all three statements every time the method is called…
[/quote]

You don’t want to use ‘else if’ there, because there are 3 different boolean variables. All, some, or none of the statements could be true.[/quote]

Not in the bank’s example. He only has a single parameter and is checking exact equality. Only one will can possibly be true, yet doesn’t have to be. That’s why I think it’d be minutely more efficient to simply use ‘else if’ statements for the second two conditionals, instead of having the JVM check them as well, even if the first (or second) were already true.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @sup000 sup000
item.description:
@sup000 wrote:

thanks for your help.

if you are interested …


/**
 * Instances of the TrafficLights class model a set of traffic lights.
 */
import ou.*;
public class TrafficLights 
{
   /* instance variables */
   private Circle stopLight;
   private Circle readyLight;
   private Circle goLight;
   private Square background;
   private int xPos;
   private int yPos;
   
   /**
    * Default constructor for objects of class TrafficLights
    */
   public TrafficLights()
   {
      super();
      xPos = 75;
      yPos = 100;      
   }
  
   
   /**
    * Gets the receiver's xPos
    */    
   public int getXPos()
   {
       return this.xPos;
   }
   
   

   /**
    * Sets the receiver's xPos
    */    
   public void setXPos(int x)
   {
       this.xPos = x;
   }
   

   /**
    * Gets the receiver's yPos
    */    
   public int getYPos()
   {
       return this.yPos;
   } 
   
   
   /**
    * Sets the receiver's yPos
    */    
   public void setYPos(int y)
   {
       this.xPos = y;
   }    
       
   
   /**
    * Returns the receiver's stopLight
    */
   public Circle getStopLight()
   {
       return this.stopLight;
   } 
   
   
   /**
    * Returns the receiver's readyLight
    */
   public Circle getReadyLight()
   {
       return this.readyLight;
   } 
   
   
   /**
    * Returns the receiver's goLight
    */   
   public Circle getGoLight()
   {
       return this.goLight;
   } 
   
   
   /**
    * Returns the receiver's background
    */   
   public Square getBackground()
   {
       return this.background;
   } 
   
   
   /**
    * Sets the receiver's stopLight
    */   
   public void setStopLight(Circle aCircle)
   {
       this.stopLight = aCircle;
   }   
   
   
   /**
    * Sets the receiver's readyLight
    */    
   public void setReadyLight(Circle aCircle)
   {
       this.readyLight = aCircle;
   }
   
   
   /**
    * Sets the receiver's goLight
    */    
   public void setGoLight(Circle aCircle)
   {
       this.goLight = aCircle;
   }
   
   

   /**
    * Sets the receiver's background
    */   
   public void setBackground(Square aSquare)
   {
       this.background = aSquare;
   }    
    
       
       
   /**
    * Changes the state of the Square object referenced by the method's formal
    * argument sq so that it represents a black square of length 150, with its 
    * left hand uppermost corner at the coordinates given by the values of the 
    * xPos and yPos instance variables of the receiver.
    * Finally the receiver's background is set to sq.
    */      
   public void addBackground(Square sq)
   {
      sq.setLength(150);
      sq.setColour(OUColour.BLUE);
      sq.setXPos(xPos);
      sq.setYPos(yPos);
      setBackground(sq);
  
   }

   
   /**
    * Sets the colour, diameter, xPos and yPos of the circles referenced
    * by the formal arguments to appropriate values.
    * Then the receiver's instance variables stopLight, readyLight 
    * and goLight are set respectively to the arguments red, amber and green.
    */  
   public void addLights(Circle red, Circle amber, Circle green)
   {   
      
      red.setColour(OUColour.RED);
      red.setDiameter(50);
      red.setXPos(xPos + 50);
      red.setYPos(yPos);
      amber.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
      amber.setDiameter(50);
      amber.setXPos(xPos + 50);
      amber.setYPos(yPos + 50);
      green.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
      green.setDiameter(50);
      green.setXPos(xPos + 50);
      green.setYPos(yPos + 100);
      setStopLight(red);
      setGoLight(green);
      setReadyLight(amber);
  
   }
   
     /**
    * String argument, red amber or green, set the object 
    * referenced by the the instance variable relative to the argument
    *eg. red = stopLight, amber = readyLight, red = goLight to BLACK
    *
    */

   public void switchOff(String light) 
   {
      if(light.equals("red"))
         stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
      if(light.equals("amber"))
         readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
      if(light.equals("green"))
         goLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); 
   }
   
   public void switchOn(String light)
   {
      if(light.equals("red")) 
         stopLight.setColour(OUColour.RED);
      if(light.equals("amber"))
         readyLight.setColour(OUColour.ORANGE);
      if(light.equals("green"))
         goLight.setColour(OUColour.GREEN);
   }   
   
   /** from stop to readyToGo  
    */
   public void readyToGo()
   {
      switchOn("amber");      
   }
   
   /** from readyToGo to go
    */
   public void go()
   {
      switchOff("red");
      switchOff("amber");
      switchOn("green");      
   }
   
   /** from go to readyToStop
    */
   public void readyToStop()
   {
      switchOff("green");
      switchOn("amber"); 
   }
   
   /** from readyToStop to stop
    */
   public void stop()
   {
      switchOff("amber");
      switchOn("red");
   }
   
   /** cycles through the lights the user specified amount of times.
   * */
   public void sequence()
   {
      String inputCycles;// = new String();
      int intCycles;
      int completedCycles; //loop

      inputCycles = OUDialog.request("How many cycles would you like displayed?");
      intCycles = Integer.parseInt(inputCycles); // convert string to integer
      
      completedCycles = 0;
      while (completedCycles < intCycles)
      {
         readyToGo();
         this.delay(1000);
         go();
         this.delay(1000);
         readyToStop();
         this.delay(1000);
         stop();
         this.delay(1000);
         completedCycles++;    
      
   }
   
}
   /**
    * Causes execution to pause by time number of milliseconds
    */
   private void delay(int time)
   {
      try
      {
         Thread.sleep(time); 
      }
      catch (Exception e)
      {
         System.out.println(e);
      } 
   }
  
}

c+c if you like, tabbing is crap and obviously Circle and Square are seperate classes. Tested with the following code

Square b = new Square();
TrafficLights t = new TrafficLights();
t.addBackground(b);
Circle red = new Circle();
Circle amber = new Circle();
Circle green = new Circle();
t.addLights(red, amber, green);
t.sequence();

Read full topic

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“sup000, post:13, topic:249929”]the method returns false which is why i presumed there was an error in my interpretation[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 11, 2008, 04:02:51 am[/size][hr][quote author=the bank link=topic=329482.msg2576203#msg2576203 date=1228962993]

public void switchOff(String red, String amber, String green) { if(red.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(amber.equals("off")) readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(green.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); //This is what you put in your code...however I think you mean to use startLight or something }Pass it the string “off” to call the corresponding method.

[/quote]
the question is as follows;

Write a public instance method for the TrafficLights class called switchOff(), the method takes a single String argument which you may assume will always be “red”, “amber” or “green”.

It then goes to say about the different arguments affecting the different light’s results[/quote]That’s fucking stupid. But here:

public void switchOff(String light) { if(light.equals("red") stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(light.equals("amber") readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(light.equals("green") stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); //This is what you put in your code...however I think you mean to use startLight or something }You could use an “else” block, I chose not to.

What the fuck is wrong with your teacher?

Read full topic

the method returns false which is why i presumed there was an error in my interpretation[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 11, 2008, 04:02:51 am[/size][hr][quote=“the bank, post:12, topic:249929”]public void switchOff(String red, String amber, String green) { if(red.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(amber.equals("off")) readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(green.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); //This is what you put in your code...however I think you mean to use startLight or something }Pass it the string “off” to call the corresponding method.[/quote]

It then goes to say about the different arguments affecting the different light's results

public void switchOff(String red, String amber, String green) { if(red.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(amber.equals("off")) readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(green.equals("off")) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); //This is what you put in your code...however I think you mean to use startLight or something }Pass it the string “off” to call the corresponding method.

Also, yes, it should go into the negative.

What happens instead?

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @sup000 sup000
item.description:
@sup000 wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:2, topic:249929”][code]public void switchColor(String color) {
switch(color) {
case “red”:
//switch the colors to equal red
break;

//etc etc etc etc[/code]You should get the basic idea…you could also use a series of “if” conditions instead of a switch statement.

I’m surprised they didn’t teach you this…

EDIT:

Nevermind, I see what you mean now…try this:

public void switchOff(boolean red, boolean amber, boolean green) { if(red) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(amber) readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); if(green) stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK); //This is what you put in your code...however I think you mean to use startLight or something }[/quote]

in the question, it specifically states that the argument would be a string, in this case it is a boolean, or am i missing it?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 10, 2008, 04:34:53 pm[/size][hr][quote=“the bank, post:9, topic:249929”]How are you initializing the accounts and post the transfer method.[/quote]

the method description reads;

boolean transfer(Account toAccount, double anAmount)

i can only assume we go into a negative answer

EDIT: sorry the accounts are initilised Account account1 = new Account();, the account class is provided

Read full topic

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Assuming your Account.transfer(Account dest, int amount) function is similar to the following:

[code]public void transfer(Account dest, int amount) {
this.debit(amount); // remove da moneyz
dest.credit(amount); // give da other guy moneyz

if (this.funds < 0) {
    this.debit(9999999); // omfg overdraft feeez!!
}

}[/code]

Then yes, account1.getFunds() should return a negative value.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Please
item.dc:creator: @sup000 sup000
item.description:
@sup000 wrote:

on a side note, could you look at the below for me?;

account1.credit(100);
account2.credit(150);
account1.transfer(account2, 120);

in my eyes, supposing the objects were correctly initilised, this will leave account 1 in the negative. I have read and read and understood that the message transfer is being send to account1 to send the funds to account2 thus leaving account1 in a negative. this just seems strange for an example. so maybe im wrong and the money is being sent to account2.

ta

item.title: Help Please

any help will be well recieved…

/**
    * String argument, red amber or green, set the object 
    * referenced by the the instance variable relative to the argument
    *eg. red = stopLight, amber = readyLight, red = goLight to BLACK
    *
    */
   
   public void swichOff(String red, String amber, String green)
   {
   //   red = stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
  //    amber = readyLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);
    //  green = stopLight.setColour(OUColour.BLACK);

the instances are created elsewhere and the idea is to set the light, specifiied by the method argument, to black simulating the light is off.

cheers, mental blocks are starting to cost me
